![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b83e507d-d466-414b-827b-714d4bde19a6)
It is stated that parallel paths should end in the same join node.

What about the following flow?
```java
CompletableFuture<Type> f = CompletableFuture.anyOf(
    CompletableFuture.runAsync(() -&gt; method1()),
    CompletableFuture.runAsync(() -&gt; method2())
).thenApply(_void -&gt; result());
```

This code waits for **one of the two** parallel path to complete, and proceed with the next action.

Please refer to the [github documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-your-project/creating-and-editing-commits/changing-a-commit-message#) for your reference.

In short, you can use `git commit --amend` for rewriting latest commit
And as week 3 material, `git rebase -i` for rewriting past commits.

Just note that these commands is essentially creating a new commit to replace the old commit that you want to replace, so it is not exactly just an edit to the commit message

Please correct me if I'm wrong.

Referring to oracle's documentation on [managing files](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/package/managingfiles.html):

> Many implementations of the Java platform rely on hierarchical file systems to manage source and class files, although The Java Language Specification does not require this. 

So I believe it is a common convention that is followed by most java platforms, that you should match example.myFile.Abc to the file path `./example/myFile/Abc.java`. The main point here is `Many implementations of the Java platform rely on hierarchical file systems to manage source and class files`, so I guess thats the purpose of needing packages' names to follow the folder path of where the file is.

I might be wrong, but one of the reason could be, when compiler sees
```
// Abc.java file
package example.myFile;
```
, it creates a corresponding Abc.class file at 
```{``outputPath``}``/example/myFile/Abc.class`

Assuming this is the default behaviour of the compiler, it seems logical to me why packages name should follow the folder path, so to match the java filepaths and the class filepaths.

> Why is varargs unable to determine if a call is passing correct type parameters?

Because varargs are arrays, and you are trying to pass in an Array of generics. They don't go well together.

This was mentioned in cs2030s [here](https://nus-cs2030s.github.io/2324-s2/24-erasure.html#generics-and-arrays-cant-mix)

> But ArrayList&lt;Pair&lt;String, String>> also reduces to ArrayList during runtime, but the compiler is able to check at compile time if all method calls obey the correct parameter.

Likewise, mentioned [here](https://nus-cs2030s.github.io/2324-s2/25-unchecked.html)

I feel that the cs2030s notes explained it quite concisely so I won't provide a TLDR â˜¹  

> then is there not much advantage over just passing a new array that the compiler would inserted in compiletime, with the benefit of not dealing with unchecked exceptions?

The benefit of varargs is that it accepts a variable number of arguments, so we don't have to overload the methods. You can't have an array parameter with variable size.
</panel>

**7. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡ GH Actions CI/CD failing because jUnit tests fail due to missing whitespaces (Multiline string issues)**
</div>

Is this you:

```sh
UiCliTest > testPrintError() FAILED
    org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: expected: <|  Error message here!
    |  Multiline Error Message
    > but was: < |  Error message here!
     |  Multiline Error Message
    >
```


And does IntelliJ tell you to use multiline strings?
```java
final String expected = """ |  Error message here!
                            |  Multiline Error Message
                               """;
```

---

The error is obvious when you reformat this error line:

expected:
```sh 
|  Error message here!
|  Multiline Error Message
 
```

but was: 
```sh
 |  Error message here!
 |  Multiline Error Message
 
```

What you can do is to simply break the multiline string into consecutively concatenated strings. 
```java
final String expected = " |  Error message here!\n"
                      + " |  Multiline Error Message\n";
```

You have better control on whether **the spaces are indentation or intended leading whitespaces**.


</panel>

**19 :fas-comment:**
</div>

If you want to use `Commands` as enum, then use a hashmap `string -&gt; Commands`. If it's static final, then it's allocated once and O(1) effectively. Your switch case can take the value returned by the hashmap.

I am pretty sure that the efficiency of switch cases are in that the input is directly used to jump to an offset on the table (that's why we need to break out of the table at end of each case), through `tableswitch` JVM opcode. Whereas with strings it will just run a `tablelookup` JVM opcode to run a optimised `.equals()` for every case until hit. 

I argue that: 

> String -&gt; Hash -&gt; Hashmap<String, Commands> -&gt; Commands -&gt; switch(Commands) -&gt; jump to case

is faster and more efficient than

> String -&gt; `tablelookup` of O(n) -&gt; jump to case

---

I also argue that it is easier to maintain because you can simply edit the text the user needs to input to run the command:

```java
// Commands is enum
HashMap<String, Commands> commandsMap = new HashMap<>();
commandsMap.put("list", Commands.LIST);
commandsMap.put("delete", Commands.DELETE);

...
// input is String
switch(commandsMap.get(input.lowerCase())) ``{``
case Commands.LIST:
   < Many lines of logic >
   ....
   ....
case Commands.DELETE:
  < More more LoC>
   ....
   ....
``}``
```

Suppose tomorrow we gonna **i18n** to worldwide.
We will not want to *manually edit each and every single switch case*!!!

we can simply do this:

```java
// Commands is enum
HashMap<String, Commands> commandsMap = new HashMap<>();

// english
commandsMap.put("list", Commands.LIST);
commandsMap.put("delete", Commands.DELETE);
// tamil
commandsMap.put("à®ªà®Ÿà¯à®Ÿà®¿à®¯à®²à®¿à®Ÿà¯à®•à®µà¯à®®à¯", Commands.LIST);
commandsMap.put("à®…à®´à®¿à®•à¯à®•à®µà¯à®®à¯", Commands.DELETE);
// mandarin
commandsMap.put("åˆ—å°", Commands.LIST);
commandsMap.put("åˆ é™¤", Commands.DELETE);
```

and you never need to touch the switch case ever again.

If  InputState ---Command--> OutputState is deterministic, think about how we'd do it for another input/output:

```java
// testing function "int square(int)"
int input = 3;
int expected = 9;
int output = square(input);
assertEqual(expected, output);
```

So for your command you're testing,

```java
// testing function "oogaBooga(TaskList t)"
TaskList list = new TaskList(Task a, Task b);
int expected = new TaskList(Task x, Task y);
oogaBooga(list);
assertEqual(expected, list);
```

If you do this you **will fail** because by default, all Object subclasses'  `.equals(Object other)` will compare the pointer address in the heap. What you need to do is to Override `.equals(Object other)` like we did in CS2040S. so you can compare if the new state of `list` is exactly what you expected in `expected`.

This will let you:
1. Test the command function
2. Not touch the `TaskList` private functions
</panel>

**TL;DR** because `*` by default does not include _hidden files_ (starting with `.`). to include them you need to also run `git add .*`.
---

`*` wildcard (globbing) is not a git-specific thing, but dependent on the shell you are running. Shells like _bash_ and _zsh_ define the behaviour of what `*` globs. You can edit them in their respective config / `rc` files.

The default behaviour of `*` only includes non-hidden files, which means anything starting with `.`, ie `.gitignore`, will be ignored.

---

- `git add -A` or `git add -All` If you're trying to add *ALL* files (that are not excluded by `.gitignore`)
- `git add -u` if you only want to add all **currently tracked** files (**This is most often used**)
- `git add -f &lt;File>` to forcefully stage a _currently ignored_ file. 
</panel>

> After understanding what I need to interface with the GUI, I've come to the conclusion that my current codebase needs quite a bit of refactoring.

If it's to do with the main loop depending on `Scanner` blocking until input is available, you can get around with:

&lt;details> &lt;summary> what i did basically &lt;/summary>

1. extracting that `hasNext()` into an abstract method in `Ui` interface
2. have 2 different classes implement `Ui`, with the *cli* version's `hasNext` `running scanner.hasNext()`
3. **Cry** for awhile realising you need to implement some concurrency stream implementation for GUI (**This is important** because you know you should not exert too much effort into this but you can't help it)
4. Make your UiGui implementation of `Ui` hold a buffer of input and outputs. Basically instead of `System.out.println` going to `STDOUT` and scanner reading from `STDIN`, implement a _blocking_ function to busy wait until the input buffer / output buffer is not empty anymore and return true (or return false when your bot has ended, indicating a _closed stream_)
5. Run your bot in a new `Thread` so that it will concurrently pull from `UiGui`-IN and push to `UiGui`-OUT
6. Run another loop in your `MainWindow` (probably in the init method) class to run a new `Thread` to repeatably check if the Output buffer is not empty, and then _print_ it out as the bot's dialogbox

&lt;/details>

**tl;dr**
1. encapsulate Ui to be an interface doing the STDIN/OUT/ERR. Cli implementation can use normal System.out and System.in
2. Run your bot in a new thread so that it can _busy wait_ for _Input_
3. Run a seperate thread in your GUI application to _busy wait_ for _Output_ and **signal the main app to add new `DialogBox`s when output availabe (ie bot replies)**

Some caveats:
- &lt;details> &lt;summary> JavaFX updates must happen on the JavaFX line. &lt;/summary> Use `Platform.runLater(updateMethod)` to run a `updateMethod()` that does the `Ui.StdOut->DialogBox->Add to scene` &lt;/details>
- &lt;details> &lt;summary> I had to use a flag to add a guard clause in my update method. &lt;/summary> Idk why even though I only execute the `runLater` when the busyloop continues, it still gets stuck afterwards. _I think `Platform.runLater` might be executed once, so the new thread only needs to update the flag and not call it again. I will need to try this._ &lt;/details>
- Your program will be a bit slower on startup.

Why I did it this way:

I believe both does the work, but if you're pushing to production, compiling **without** the -ea flag will silent all `assert` statements, even if triggered. Throwing AssertionError means in production release your product might throw an error to the very very confused user (if it is not caught or handled). very evil but I don't trust the user to handle AssertionErrors, even though the programme will now be in an undefined state. I guess that's up for discussion 

also note that unless you `catch (Error e)` or `catch (Throwable e)`, it won't be caught. Usually we catch `Exception`s but never catch `Error`s (unless threading i think).

IIRC usually you declare the variable before the switch, but don't assign it. Then in each case statement you can assign the Id.

I see "Type x = y" as actually 2 different operations, a definition and assignment. So you can break it into 2 statements and then the common statement (ie the definition) will be brought out to before the switch. 

Personally I try to extract as much common statements out as possible, and make each case statement only what's specific to the case. 

```java
int id;

switch (command) ``{``
case MarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
    id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new MarkCommand(taskList, id);

case UnmarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD: 
    id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new UnmarkCommand(taskList, id);
``}`` 
```
(I'm assuming `id` will have different assignment in other cases? If not you can also just straight away assign it before the switch) 

But I like the brackets too, they help define the local scope. Reminds me of rust `match` blocks. 
</panel>

you can also skip (2) by:
1. declaring your `Task` as a `abstract class Task<T extends Task>`
2. Make the factory method return a new `T`
3. Make your subclasses extend `Task` like `class Deadline extends Task<Deadline>`

I have a base command class, which takes in the string slices and pushes them into hashmaps. Then each subclass that extends this class has a `runCommand` method that will look into the hashmap for required arguments. This also frees up the argument order, since the parsing method sees the command as:

```VERB [first argument] [/flag1 [flag1 arguments]] ... [/flagN [flagN arguments]]```

<details> 

<summary> I also did something more complicated </summary>

</div>

Have a look at #184, there is discussion regarding whether arrowhead-switch statements should be indented or not, since SE-EDU guidelines predate this feature.

Your issue is related to the fact that the SE-EDU guideline, as well as checkstyle, was never designed with _switch expressions_ (ie switch blocks that evaluates to a value) in mind. So consequently it was not designed for `switch` to be pushed in from its statement's indentation level.

So the question here is, do you want the `case` statements to align the level of the statement that has `switch`, or do you want it to be _1 level left_ from the `switch` line's indentation level? 

#184 prefers the latter (what your ide is doing now), but checkstyle will disagree. It's very whishy-woshy. 

You can use and abuse the checkstyle-suppression and intellij-suppression comments to disable checking this block in the meantime, and manually adjust the spacing.
</panel>

I talked about it [here](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/255#issuecomment-2342348083)

Final variables only mean they are immutanle _for each object instance_ but making it static final means they are _globally immutable_. 

JVM will store _static final_ separately in the program `DATA` section, but finals without static will still be allocated on heap with each instance of the class initialised. 

---

Now, some standards agree that finals should also be ALL_CAPS. Some don't. For this course, we reserve this to only the static finals.

There's an option in the `checkstyle.xml` if you wanna disable it, for future uses
</panel>

**TLDR**

- Performance wise: no impact (on release). 
- Use until ~~shiok~~ you feel it is enough / it starts diminishing in value of readability
- asserts are a _debugging / development_ tool - assume they will vanish in prod and use guard clauses instead for unavoidable exception states that can happen in prod, so that the programme _gently_ errors out and not explode in the user's face or silently run in an invalid state. 

----

Java is mostly JIT-compilation and without explicit `-ea` flag, the JIT-compiler will drop the `assert` bytecodes. `assert` statements are in theory supposed to be ignored in release files (ie for debugging purposes). You cannot have assert statements annihilating the whole program - you want to fail silently (and *log* it). So in testing, you'd run `java` with `-ea` flag (**enable assertions**). 

By default, the behaviour is to run with assertions disabled (`-da`)[&hat;1]. 

[&hat;1]: More on the flag [here](https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19683-01/806-7930/6jgp65ikq/index.html), including how to specifically choose which class to enable and disable assertions with the cli flags

----

2103 being 2103, it's a perfect qn to ask in terms of code quality, ask yourself:

**Can you understand the code you wrote yesterday with the assert statements everywhere?**:
- Yes: ~~not enough asserts~~ it's fine
- No: stop. 
  - That being said, I feel like asserts should ideally start/end a segment of code. You need to break your wall of code with newlines. Else it feels like reading an essay with no paragraphs. 
  - `assert model != null` is duplicating the `requireNonNull(model)` code. 

----

I also agree with @Incogdino. Ask yourself if the checks are:
- recoverable exceptions; or
- unrecoverable errors / invalid states

A user entering invalid command is still a valid state with an exception that you raise and then catch and process. That should be *in the release*. 

A user entering invalid command and the app successfully accepts without throwing exception? That is an invalid state - it should be caught in development and the program must burn and crash. 

If you think it that a "not happy" state can be encountered in production and should be *recoverable*, hmhm, like how AB3 is able to populate a new `addressbook.json` if it is missing / is corrupted (This means it is not an _invalid state_ - it's just another valid state with exception), then you may want to "incorporate" this assert checking into actual code as an exception instead. 


</panel>

**97 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Also, overloading occurs within the class, and you can think of it as "one name, different flavours". You can say that the same name is _overloaded_ with different possible input variables. **different signatures**

Overriding is "hiding" the inherited function and putting a brand new function _over_ it. You can say that it _overrides_ the parent function. **same signature**.

---

If you dig deeper, Overriding is processed ~~compile time (javac)~~ runtime (jvm) by using the new function instead of copying the parent function, which allows the object to run its own version of the method while still being able to take the place of the superclass instance.

Overloading is done in ~~runtime (jvm)~~ compile time (javac) where ~~jvm~~ javac does some weird stuff to decides to widen the scope or unbox the passed variable, Lowkey like on-the-spot overriding but that's not impt. (unfortunately it's not syntatic sugar like other languages that does function mangling, where overloading is secretly having two different functions that the compiler will resolve for you) 
</panel>

My bad. Yes it's the other way. Overriding is runtime (jvm) since the funky subclass superclass thingies aren't known until runtime

Overloading is compiletime (javac) where the method is appropriately modified to match the signature in one of many ways supported by javac

**21 :fas-comment:**
</div>

A fast forward merge happens when the master branch (or any other branch) have not changed from the branch you are merging to. In this case, git just moves the master branch to the same commit as the merging branch. 

A merge commit happens when both the master branch and merging branch have different unique commits. Instead of just moving the master branch forward to the merging branch, git will "merge" both branches as a new commit. This new commit will have two parent commits, one from each of the branch. 

Here is an image I found online that illustrates this 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e7168419-24b3-4bda-a8a0-3904ec7a3641)


I guess the only difference here is that a new commit is made whenever a merge is done for merge commits while fast forward will not have a new commit. 

To my knowledge, this is what happens. Hopefully it answers your question. Please correct me if I'm wrong. 
</panel>

The issue most likely arose when you initialised `FileWriter` at the start with override. 

If you are not using `FileWriter(String path, boolean append)`, `FileWriter` will open the file in override mode and thus wipe out all existing data. 

In this case, I guess you have two options
1. Initialize `FileWriter` with the additional boolean argument, `FileWriter(String path, boolean append)`
2. Initialize `FileWriter` when the program is exiting with `FileWriter(String path)`

Hope this solves your issue :)
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/84#issuecomment-2313037666" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**27 :fas-comment:**
</div>

The reason this happens is because you keep creating a new instance of the scanner every time the loop repeats.

When the first instance of the scanner is created, it takes in an input. When ran without a script, this is the user keyboard input. When ran with a script, this is the input text file provided. 

Thus on every loop iteration, a new instance of the scanner means that the previous input stream gets reset and it awaits for new user/ file input. Since there is no other file supplied, you get the error that you see, "Exception in thread "main" java.util.NoSuchElementException: No line found". The program then terminates and gives you the mismatch between your expected and actual files.

To resolve this, you can create your scanner instance outside of the while loop. 
</panel>

Git does a fast forward commit when the master branch is behind the branch of your current branch, branch level 7 when there is no diverging commits in your master branch and your branch level 7. 

A fast forward commit then takes the pointer of the master branch and moves it to the branch level 7 commit and thus they have the same commit hashes.

Ahh sorry misread the question. 

In this case, you should still define the `fx:controller` to `MainWindow`. As per my understanding, the `fx:controller` is just a bridge that links your java file with the GUI so that the class knows what methods to call.

```java
<fx:root type="AnchorPane" maxHeight="-Infinity" maxWidth="-Infinity"
         minHeight="-Infinity" minWidth="-Infinity"
         prefHeight="600.0" prefWidth="400.0"
         xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17"
         xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" fx:controller="MainWindow">
```

To then run the program, 
```java
    public void start(Stage primaryStage) ``{``
        try ``{``
            FXMLLoader fxmlLoader = new FXMLLoader(Main.class.getResource("/view/MainWindow.fxml"));
           
            // Set the root node
            AnchorPane rootNode = new AnchorPane();
            fxmlLoader.setRoot(rootNode);
            
            // Load the FXML file
            AnchorPane root = fxmlLoader.load();

            // Get the controller and pass the Duke instance
            MainWindow mainWindow = fxmlLoader.getController();
            mainWindow.setDuke(duke);

            // Set the scene and show the stage
            Scene scene = new Scene(root);
            primaryStage.setScene(scene);
            primaryStage.setTitle("Duke");
            primaryStage.show();
        ``}`` catch (IOException e) ``{``
            e.printStackTrace();
        ``}``
    ``}``
```

> But the requirement is that we convert MainWindow to use the fx:root construct.

This means that `fx:root` provides a way to create the Node as the component we specify and then to use that node as its root. Instead of having another instance node to wrap this class the represents it. You can find more details [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23600926/how-to-understand-and-use-fxroot-in-javafx) and [here](https://docs.oracle.com/javafx/2/api/javafx/fxml/doc-files/introduction_to_fxml.html#root_elements).

But it seems as though your assertions are calling other methods here. Without knowing too much details of what the methods does, I do not think is very much a good idea. 

For instance, `model.hasLessons(lesson)` should be more like an exception (or a guard clause) rather than an assertion.

**10. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on stating a `response.NotInScope`**
</div>

<img width="550" alt="Screenshot 2024-11-10 at 1 59 59â€¯AM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1049f58b-5015-46c8-9d10-65112501fc2f">

This is an issue raised from PE-D by one of our tester. It has been labeled severity.Medium and type.FeatureFlaw

Our team has some question
Our Product is designed for Singapore local tuition centre management for primary or secondary students.

**Main Question**
Currently our team had limit the input to `Subjects` that are usually offered in tuition centres in Singapore. It is implemented using `enum`. This is to prevent user to input some invalid subjects. We do concern that this might cause some inconvenience as the field is fixed. But we had future plan for implementing these feature for subject management.
- `newSubject`: Allow user to define their own subject that offered in tuition centre

# Use of AI Tools in the Project
(This is from my iP AI.md file)
## Introduction

Several AI tools are used in the development of the project (Toothless Chatbot). The AI tools employed in this project are ChatGPT, Claude, and GitHub Copilot. These AI tools have enhanced the coding workflow, improved productivity, and raised quality standards in the project.

## AI Tools Used

### 1. ChatGPT and Claude

These two AI tools are primarily used to enhance written communication, code explanation, and problem-solving for the project.

#### Applications

- **Improving Documentation**: These AI tools are mainly used as writing assistants to refine user guides, README files, and PR descriptions.
- **Enhancing Code-Related Communication**: They are also used to improve grammar and clarity in PR descriptions and aid in generating informative and standardized commit messages.
- **Problem Solving and Ideation**: The tools are used to aid in brainstorming feature ideas and implementation strategies. Sometimes they are used to suggest alternative approaches to enhance feature functionalities.

#### Things to Note When Using ChatGPT and Claude
- **Review and Refinement**: Always review and refine the generated content to ensure accuracy and relevance to the project. As sometime the review given might be irrelevant to the project or out of the context of the project.
- **Use in Specific Contexts**: Use these tools in specific contexts where they can provide the most value, such as documentation, communication, and ideation. Try to give the prompt in such a way that the AI can understand the context of the project, so they can give more accurate suggestions.
- **Avoid Over-Reliance**: Avoid over-reliance on AI-generated content and ensure that the final output aligns with the project's goals and requirements. As the AI can give suggestions but the developer should been the one to give ideation and make the final decisions.

### 2. GitHub Copilot

Copilot is mainly used as a real-time coding assistant to enhance the productivity of the project.

#### Applications

- **Code Generation**: It is used to suggest complete functions based on comments or function names. It suggests boilerplate code for common patterns. It also aids in autocompleting repetitive structures such as loop constructs and error handling.
- **API and Library Usage**: It also suggests library functions and methods to be used to create project features. It can also aid in autocompleting import statements for required modules.
- **Error Handling and Debugging**: Copilot also aids in error handling by providing quick fixes for common errors like syntax errors. It can also be used to aid in debugging by suggesting possible causes of bugs or errors.
- **Context-Aware Assistance**: It provides relevant code snippets based on the surrounding code context and suggests variable names that align with existing naming patterns.
- **Documentation**: It also aids in completing documentation such as writing header comments for classes and functions.

#### Things to Note When Using GitHub Copilot
- **Code Review and Refinement**: Always review and refine the code generated by Copilot to ensure correctness and alignment with project standards as sometime Copilot can give suggestions that are not relevant to the project.
- **Use in Specific Contexts**: Utilize Copilot in specific contexts where it can provide the most value, such as code generation, debugging, and documentation. These can let Copilot to give more detailed and accurate suggestions.
- **Avoid Over Reliance**: Avoid over-reliance on Copilot-generated code to avoid substituting fundamental coding skills with AI assistance. Always ensure that the code align with the project requirement and understand how the code works. 

## Benefits of AI Integration in the Project

1. **Efficiency**: Using these tools significantly reduces time spent on routine coding tasks, documentation, and problem-solving.
2. **Learning and Skill Development**: Accelerates learning of new concepts and coding skills when the tools are used appropriately.
3. **Communication**: Enhances the clarity and effectiveness of code-related communications.
4. **Reduced Cognitive Load**: Handles low-level details and allows developers to focus on higher-level problem-solving.

## Things to Note When Using AI Tools in Development of the Project

1. **Critical Review**: Always review and understand AI-generated content before incorporation, as it may not always be correct or suitable for use. Reviewing and understanding the content also helps avoid over-reliance on AI for coding, which may hinder developers from gaining knowledge through the project.
2. **Use it as Augmentation, Not Replacement**: Use AI to enhance the project development but not as a substitute for fundamental coding skills.
3. **Balance of using AI and Human Skills**: Ensure to maintain a balance between AI assistance and human creativity to preserve the project's unique aspects and learning purpose in building the project.

## Conclusion

The integration of ChatGPT, Claude, and GitHub Copilot has significantly enhanced my iP development process, especially in improving code quality, documentation, and overall productivity.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**4. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Using Checkstyle with the agreed convention for the arrow-hand switch case notation.**
</div>

As mentioned in #49, the preferred switch case convention with the arrow-hand notation is as such:
```Java
TaskType taskType = switch (data.charAt(0)) ``{``
    case 'T' -&gt; TaskType.TODO;
    case 'E' -&gt; TaskType.EVENT;
    case 'D' -&gt; TaskType.DEADLINE;
    default -&gt; TaskType.UNKNOWN;
``}``; 
```

However, this goes against the indentation rule where cases are supposed to be indented by `0`. 
If the `@SuppressWarnings` annotation is attempted to be used, the script still flags for this build mistake.

Instead, use the inbuilt SuppressionCommentFilter:
```Java
<module name="SuppressionCommentFilter">
            <property name="offCommentFormat" value="CHECKSTYLE.OFF\: ([\w\|]+)"/>
            <property name="onCommentFormat" value="CHECKSTYLE.ON\: ([\w\|]+)"/>
            <property name="checkFormat" value="$1"/>
        </module>
```

and add the comments above and below: for example:

```Java
// CHECKSTYLE.OFF: Indentation
TaskType taskType = switch (data.charAt(0)) ``{``
    case 'T' -&gt; TaskType.TODO;
    case 'E' -&gt; TaskType.EVENT;
    case 'D' -&gt; TaskType.DEADLINE;
    default -&gt; TaskType.UNKNOWN;
``}``; 
// CHECKSTYLE.ON: Indentation
```

which will disable the Indentation rule for the area between the two comments.

> Note: only use this if you're sure that your code matches the convention. In this scenario, a new Checkstyle custom rule is required since it does not recognise the arrow-notation, so this is a less taxing way of building without flagging the Checkstyle.
</panel>

Yep, hence why it is generally just better to have a local copy on both machines and push everytime you want to move to the other machine. The convenience of syncing ala-GDrive/OneDrive may be lost, but you're a lot more likely to not run into unexpected behaviour. (for example, editing on one side, then editing on the other PC and the syncing causing some conflict within the changed file).

Git also has some behaviour that isn't seen sometimes when you do push which is helpful for maintaining code across different OSes - `core.autocrlf` for example is a Git setting that helps manage line separators (that differ in Mac and Windows)

application ``{``

## CLI-App

I had a dedicated printing class at first when I was still working on the CLI-App. The excerpt below is of my printer class from then:

``` java
public class FormattedPrinting ``{``

    public static void formatPrint(String message) ``{``
        String indentation = "   ";
        String separatorLine = indentation + "______________________________________________________";
        StringBuilder outputMessage = new StringBuilder(separatorLine);
        String[] messageLines = message.split("\n");
        for (String line : messageLines) ``{``
            outputMessage.append("\n")
                    .append(indentation)
                    .append(line);
        ``}``
        outputMessage.append("\n")
                .append(separatorLine);
        System.out.println(outputMessage.toString());
    ``}``

    public static void welcome() ``{``
        String welcomeMessage = "Hello I'm Mortal Reminder!\n"
                + "What can I do for you?";
        formatPrint(welcomeMessage);

    ``}``
``}``
```


The first method allowed all of my print classes to have a consistent format in the printing styles. This class also mostly consisted of static methods (as seen in the second method) which could be called from other classes without instantiating an object of said class.

## GUI-App
Later on, specifically after I moved to GUI-App, I realised this method was kind of becoming redundant as the GUI basically handled all of the formatting for me. As such, I incorporated an error class which then helped to pass in any error messages. An excerpt is shown below:

``` java
/**
     * Retrieves the task at the specified index from the list.
     * <p>
     * If the index is out of bounds or the list is empty, an appropriate message is printed
     * and ``{``@code null``}`` is returned.
     *
     * @param index the index of the task to retrieve.
     * @return the ``{``@link Task``}`` at the specified index, or ``{``@code null``}`` if the index is invalid.
     * @throws MortalReminderException if the index is invalid in the list.
     */
    public Task getTask(int index) throws MortalReminderException ``{``
        try ``{``
            return this.taskList.get(index);
        ``}`` catch (IndexOutOfBoundsException e) ``{``
            if (this.getSize() == 0) ``{``
                throw new MortalReminderException("List is empty!");
            ``}``
            throw new MortalReminderException("Invalid task number!\n"
                    + "Please input a number between 1 and "
                    + this.getSize());
        ``}``
    ``}``
```

In spirit of laziness and not wanting to re-code everything, I changed return type in the printer class to strings. I kept the first method of the printer class as the following:

``` java
/**
     * Prints out the formatted output of the chatbot to the user.
     * An indentation is added to each line and the separator lines are added at the top and bottom of each
     * line in the message.
     *
     * @param message output message from chatbot to be printed out to the user
     * @return a version of confirmation message with specific modifications.
     */
    public static String getResponse(String message) ``{``
        return message;
    ``}``

In terms of error vs assert, in this case the code could still work but the assumption could have become invalid.

An example could be like your delete function. It could assume the add method has already checked if the task is valid or not. From what I observed in your java files, I think its certainly an interesting approach to this project. 

However, I guess it would not be sustainable as the project scales as you are effectively creating 2 classes to be able to deal with a new type of task each time which in turn makes it a hassle to create a new type each time.

If you are interested, the way I reduced complexity was to keep the creation methods into the class itself and then add a single dedicated check method for the main initialization method (creation from user) so something like:


```java
    // for creation from user input
    public Deadline(String description) throws MortalReminderException ``{``
        super(description);
        String[] descriptionString = description.split("/by");
        checkInitialisationDetails(descriptionString);
        this.description = descriptionString[0].trim();
        this.deadline = getTime(descriptionString[1].trim());
        this.type = "D"; // short for Deadline
    ``}``

    // for creation from file input
    public Deadline(String description, String deadline, boolean isDone) throws MortalReminderException ``{``
        super(description);
        this.type = "D";
        this.description = description;
        this.deadline = LocalDateTime.parse(deadline);
        this.isDone = isDone;
    ``}``

    public void checkInitialisationDetails(String[] descriptionString)
            throws MortalReminderException ``{``
        if (descriptionString.length != 2) ``{``
            throw new MortalReminderException(MortalReminderException.getInvalidDeadlineDescriptionErrorMessage());
        ``}``

        try ``{``
            getTime(descriptionString[1].trim());
        ``}`` catch (DateTimeParseException e) ``{``
            throw new MortalReminderException(MortalReminderException.getInvalidDateFormatErrorMessage());
        ``}``
    ``}``
```
The reason why there is no check for the file input is because we assume it has been saved correctly by the program as it has already gone through numerous checks beforehand.

**5. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Setting Time Locale for CI build to ensure consistency between local build and on Github servers**
</div>

Hi everyone, I was trying to figure out why I was failing the CI builds but passing the build and check tests locally. 

It turns out that running JUnit tests to parse dates and times locally had a different Time Locale as compared to the github servers, causing errors. 

Thought that it would be helpful to share my findings on how to resolve this! 

**Solution: Set Time locale in the test class to ensure consistency**
To ensure consistency both locally and on Github, I realised I could use the @BeforeAll annotation for Junit tests, to set a fixed time locale. 
```java
//import required for the BeforeAll annotation
import org.junit.jupiter.api.BeforeAll;

//Inside the test class
//    @BeforeAll
    public static void setUp() ``{``
        Locale.setDefault(new Locale("en", "SG"));
        TimeZone.setDefault(TimeZone.getTimeZone("Asia/Singapore"));
    ``}``

```

Hope this helps! ðŸ‘

I believe this may have occured because of 2 possible scenarios: 

1. Intellij may have been configured to use fully qualified class names. 
To remove this, ensure that your configuration has unchecked "Use fully qualified class names"
-> Settings -&gt; codestyle -&gt; java -&gt; imports
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d3a63b39-fedd-415e-9933-ec5527a999c9)
Make sure that it is unchecked. 

2. There may have been multiple imports that has the List interface
In this scenario, Intellij may find it ambiguous on which type you are declaring, hence prompting the use of fully qualified names. If this is the case, troubleshoot to see if there are multiple imports that have this interface, and removing/deconflicting if unnecessary. 


Personally, as per what @adipanda2002 said, it may also be wise to just use  `ArrayList` instead. I did this, and hence did not encounter this error

Hope this helps :) 
 
</panel>

- ChatGPT tends to hallucinate quite a fair bit when it comes to implementing logic. I found that it is much better to handle the logic myself, then use chatGPT to do things that do not require much logic but rather laborious and repetitive. 
- For Javadoc comments, it is wise to send over the required coding style, so that the output is consistent with the course requirements

Not 100% sure but I believe that SLAP is a guideline to improve code quality. 

Abstraction can be done on many layers. I.e: A class is an abstraction of data and behaviour. Within behaviours (i.e.: certain functions) like `calculateTotal()`, there may be some sub-steps such as `calculateStepOne()` and `calculateStepTwo()`, and so there can be multiple layers of 'abstraction'. The textbook mentions that we are encouraged to identify a suitable layer of abstraction (that fits a particular context), and then suppress the more complex details to improve understandability of the code. 

However, when implementing the abstraction in code, the `SLAP` principle pushes us to avoid deeply nested code, making it difficult for other developers to understand. We should only have a single layer of abstraction per code block, in order to increase its readability. However, within a single class file, we would have multiple layers of abstraction, but each code block only has **1 layer of abstraction**. 

 
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/868#issuecomment-2490763378" expanded>

According to Wikipedia, the LSP states the following: 
`Let Ï†(x) be a property provable about objects x of type T. Then Ï†(y) should also be true for objects y of type S where S is a subtype of T `

Based on your supposition, if the `Admin` class assumes negative per cent values (and hence cannot work with positive values), then I believe this would violate the LSP. This is because Ï† in this example can refer to any function/behaviour that can be applied to the Staff class. Thus, if the admin class produces wrong results due to only having negative percent values, it does not satisfy the LSP. Essentially, the `admin` class cannot be substituted for the `staff` class, since it would result in the wrong values. 

However, if `Admin` class has the ability to handle **both positive and negative** values as the example in the textbook gives, it can be substituted in place of the staff class, hence not violating the LSP. 
 
</panel>

For **overloaded methods**, yes the methods can have the same name but parameter types(hence different method signature). The return types can be different. I like to think of overloading as variation of a method that does a similar thing on different parameters. 
e.g: `int multiply(int num)` and `double multiply(double num)`. Both of these are overloaded methods that multiply the given `num`, but work on different types, and hence have different return types. 

On the other hand, for **overriden methods**, they are meant to change the behaviour of a function that was inherited from a base class. This enables for polymorphism to occur. The return type for the derived class can be a subtype of the return type for the base class. I think we probably did something super similar in CS2030. 

e.g: Consider `Cat extends Animal`. Assume that the Animal class has a method called `MakeNoise()` that returns an `AnimalNoise` object. By `@overriding` the `MakeNoise()` function in the `Cat` class, a `CatNoise` (subtype of AnimalNoise) can be returned. 
</panel>

    ``}``

    /**
     * Parses a task from a line of text.
     *
     * @param line The line of text representing the task.
     * @return The parsed Task object.
     * @throws OptimusException If there is an issue with parsing.
     */
    private Task parseTaskFromLine(String line) throws OptimusException ``{``
        String[] parts = line.split("\\|");
        String taskType = parts[0].trim();
        boolean isDone = parts[1].trim().equals("1");

        Task task;
        if ("T".equals(taskType)) ``{``
            task = new Todo(parts[2].trim());
        ``}`` else if ("D".equals(taskType)) ``{``
            task = new Deadline(parts[2].trim(), parts[3].trim());
        ``}`` else if ("E".equals(taskType)) ``{``
            task = new Event(parts[2].trim(), parts[3].trim(), parts[4].trim());
        ``}`` else ``{``
            throw new OptimusException("Invalid task type: " + taskType);
        ``}``
        task.isDone = isDone;
        return task;
    ``}``
``}``
```

**1. :fas-info-circle: Severity of having typo when specifying filename for data modification**
</div>

Hi prof, I am currently reviewing the response of my evaluated team regarding an issue about data file naming typo.

Basically, the filename specified in the user guide is like this:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/feb3b75e-2fe3-49ea-8a45-aae37aa4fe0f)

However, the actual name of the file produced is named `talent.json`, 
![3ebbba22-263c-48a4-bc62-fdcce428bcfa](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a1d85fba-a64c-4730-9a73-c459218bffb1)

The team has accepted my bug report but they think that this is a `severity.veryLow` bug because it is just a typo in the file name, I can understand their reason but I feel like this can be a `severity.Low` bug instead because this is a critical operation that may potential ruin the data that the app needs and cause irreversible harm to the system. Imagine if the user wants to directly modify the data but ends up getting confused because of the difference between document and the actual file name, then he/she may be hesitant about whether he/she should modify this file. Even though there's only one data file in the data folder, I think this level of confusion may still arise because user cannot assume that data folder contains only one data file and `talent.json` may be used for a different purpose as compared to `talenthub.json`, so that's why I think it should be `severity.Low`.

May I just check if the above explanation is reasonable? or I should just accept team's response and agree that this should be `severity.veryLow`? Thank you!
</panel>

**10. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Duke Level-1: Allow case-insensitive comparison for user inputs using equalsIgnoreCase()**
</div>

Hello guys, just sharing a tip over here in case if you are wondering how you can make your chatbot more flexible when handling user inputs as an enhancement for user experience. I know this is not compulsory requirement for the project, but it may be helpful if you are wondering about how to do it in Java.

In Java we know that we can use `equals()` method to compare the values of two String objects instead of their references, however, we can use `equalsIgnoreCase()` method if you not only want to compare the String Objects just by values but also want the comparison to be case-insensitive. This method can be useful if you want the chatbot to response to a certain command regardless of how exactly it is spelled.

For example, if you want the chatbot to say goodbye to the user and exit regardless of whether the user inputs "Bye", "BYE", "bye" or any other form. Instead of writing 
```
if (userInput.equals("bye")) ``{``
    // Your exit logic
``}``
```
you can write something like this
```
if (userInput.equalsIgnoreCase("bye")) ``{``
    // Your exit logic
``}``
```
Hope that helps if you are seeking some improvements for your project, thank you.
</panel>

@somethingfishyfishy My reasonings when answering this question are like these:

1. Even though score of the team is discrete and finite, we may want to perform arithmetic operations on it, such as adding a score when the team wins a game or subtracting the score when the team receives a penalty, which is not supported by the enum type, (and just to add on, enum types are usually used for comparison, switch statements and other non-arithmetic operations) hence representing the team score using enum type variable is not appropriate.

2. Just like what @ITLimJiaWei has mentioned above but I would like to just add on. One of the key reason why we use enum types in our program is to ensure that our users don't enter garbage values into the system which can potentially cause a lot of errors and issues, and it is one of the way that strongly typed languages like java used to limit user input to a finite set of possible options while still ensuring type safety in the system. However, in this case you are just working with very large range of int values where you just need to check about the values and not the types. Therefore, instead of exhaustively declare each int value as a enum type value which greatly compromise the readability and performance of the program, it is better to just use conditional statement to check whether the team's score is within the acceptable range.

Hope that helps.
</panel>

But there's an easy workaround with this issue, all you need to do is just wrap the ImageView that represent the avatar in a VBox and set the alignment to `BOTTOME_CENTER` like below:

<VBox alignment="BOTTOM_CENTER">

        <property name="thirdPartyPackageRegExp" value="&hat;com\."/>
        <property name="sortImportsInGroupAlphabetically" value="true"/>

I think the association line between History and ActionX/Y are not necessary because this can be inferred from the class diagram itself. Since History object tracks references of Repeatable Interface Object(which is implemented by Action abstract class and eventually inherited by ActionX/Y classes), this implies that History would have references to ActionX and ActionY objects(as history, as indicated by the association role between History and Repeatable objects).

For the email body part, I think composition only implies that child's existence must depend on parent's existence and not the other way around. In some cases, you may initialize a parent object with some of its parts being undefined and only assign them afterwards, then this would actually imply a multiplicity of 0 for the child object. One possible case I can think of maybe is like other than Email class, I want to create a Draft Class that contains the information that I want to send but haven't finished yet, then in case when I try to save an email as a draft, I may create a Draft object in which the body is null. Hence, even though in this case body is part of the Draft, I can still have its multiplicity as 0, and the fact that Draft has-a body only implies that when I delete this draft, its body also gets deleted as well and not the other way around.


Hope these helps.
</panel>

This is a very good question, actually I am wondering the same but I guess it is safe to assume the answer to be yes. The reason why I am wondering the answer of this is because it is actually possible to be have concrete implementation in an interface, through the use of default keyword, which specifies the default behaviour of a given method signature if a class implements the interface but does not provide its own implementation. But I vaguely remember that such practice is not recommended, not sure if it is because of the presence of abstract class, but I will go and find out about this. If this is true, then I think can just assume `&lt;&lt;interface>>` discriminator implies all methods to be abstract.
2. `Adding on, I note that the overridden method update(int) in UIWidget is marked as public even though it's actual method signature is not shown, can I assume that for a class that implements an interface, the overridden methods will always be public?`
Note that a overriding method in Java can only have access modifier that is equally or more general than the access modifier of the original method. As you have already mentioned, methods in interface are implicitly public by default, hence any overriding methods in classes that implement this interface would have the access modifier to be public, therefore it is true that the overriden methods will always be public.

Hope this helps, and hopes someone can help me clarify on first part as well. I will try my best to figure out an answer and reply over here as well, thank you very much!

<div slot="header">

**39 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Ok, I have clarified a bit on the first point in my own explanation above, it seems like default keyword in interface is actually an approach to deal with legacy code and an easy fix to allow for extension of interface functionalities without breaking the existing code. Basically, before Java 8, interface is really only consists of abstract methods, but as the current codebase extends for future Java version, it is realized that adding new method signature to the interface requires all the existing classes that implement this interface to include their own implementation of this method respective, which is very time consuming and labor intensive. Therefore, they use default keyword to provide concrete implementation of the method to provide flexibility for the implementing class, which allows them to **not** provide their own implementation for a certain method in the interface. Similarly, interface also allows static methods for a similar reason as above.

However, that being said, it seems like such issue can be common in modern day software as well(interfaces of existing system may need to be extended with new methods without forcing existing classes to provide their own implementation). I understand that static method in interface can still be easy to annotate and differentiate, just by underlining them. But for default method, I can't find any info in UML Diagrams about this, probably because this is a Java language design choice and not a general info that needs to be described by UML, but I am also curious if there's a way to properly annotate default method in interface using UML.

Hi Prof @damithc, is there anything to work around this issue in UML? Thank you very much!
</panel>

**9. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡A-CI Error: Unable to push workflow**
</div>

Hi, just wanted to share for those facing this issue when attempting A-CI increment.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/50241632-a906-4df3-881e-630df4457a6c)

I solved this issue by following this [StackOverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64059610/how-to-resolve-refusing-to-allow-an-oauth-app-to-create-or-update-workflow-on).

TLDR:
1. Creating a Personal Access Token in my Github account.
> Must store the PAT string somewhere as it will not be shown again once you leave the page.
2. Enable both repo and workflows in the PAT.
3. Removing all Github credentials (follow steps below the answer).
4. Login to SourceTree with PAT.
5. Push commit again.

Additionally, if you receive errors in your CI pipeline, you can check what went wrong under the `Actions` tab of your repo.

I had issues with CheckStyle and my JUnit tests, which caused my CI to fail.
</panel>

**1. :fas-info-circle: What exactly is considered a What for code comment (with reference to AY17/18 Sem 1 Paper Q4)**
</div>

<img width="328" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2c158790-e014-4a14-9901-a51bc5564972">

&hat;In this question we are supposed to suggest 5 code quality improvements. In #891 the original poster shared his/her answers in which it was highlighted that the JavaDoc comment has issues as it should specify the "Why" and "What" of the code instead of writing the "How"(code implementation). I thought the JavaDoc comment is referring to the "What" of the code. From my understanding, "What" is about "the specification of what the code is supposed to do" and "How" is about the explanation how the code works. <br>

I think it is considered a "What" because the JavaDoc comment there describes what the code is expected to do. The "How" can be seen as the even more low-level and nitty-gritty details on how the numbers and spaces are removed + sorting + 10 letters replacement. However, I realised that the function name is "encode" - `encode(String original)`. So in another perspective, it could be considered a "How" because at the same time, the same JavaDoc description can be considered as explaining the step by step process of the code for encode, of how things should get encoded. The "What" is the encoding, i.e. if the Javadoc start with "encodes a string by removing space and numbers..." , it will sound more like a "What". <br>

While I think the main issue is that the first word of the JavaDoc should be "Removes" rather than "Remove", the main question of this case I have is whether the JavaDoc comment is still considered sufficiently a "What"? Because it seems that there can be 2 interpretations here, which feels very subjective.
</panel>

**8 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Here's my take for the question: &lt;br>
**Why "`Bar` class is overriding the `process()` method" is true** &lt;br>
`Foo` class has a method called `process()`, and `Bar` inherits class `Foo`, as indicated by the solid arrow with an unshaded arrowhead in the UML diagram. Given that there is a method `process()` in `Bar` as well, which will "clash with" `process()` in `Foo` class, `process()` in `Bar` class should be overridden to make the code work/compile. 

&lt;br>

**Why "Removing the `process()` method from the `Bar` class will not cause a compile error" is true**
As you have mentioned, The abstract method didn't state that its method is abstract, so removing it will not cause compile error. If I may rephrase, it means that `process()` in `Foo` class is not abstract. If I am not wrong, an abstract class need not have an abstract method too. Since `process()` in `Foo` is not abstract, then there is no need to define (implement) the `process()` method in `Bar`.  Thus, removing `process()` from `Bar` class will not affect anything, there won't be compile error. Since `Bar` is a child class of `Foo`, and if `process()` in Bar is removed, when a Bar Object call `process()` (e.g. `barObject.process()` then it is the `Foo's process()` that gets invoked (call the parent method). 

&lt;br>

**Why "Removing the store() method from the Bar class will cause a compile error" is true**
`Goo` is an interface with the `store()` method. Therefore, any class that implements `Goo` must have the method `store()` defined/implemented in their own class, otherwise there is compile error. Since `Bar` implements `Goo`, removing `store()` will result in compile error as it is required of `Bar` to define/implement `store()` as its methods. 

&lt;br>

The question asked for the incorrect statement (not correct statement), so (iv) is the answer as explained in the answer key. Hope this helps.
</panel>

If I may input:
You are right that we only illustrate dependencies for classes that do not have direct associations. However, for the class diagram required of that question, the direct association is from `Handout` class to `Section` class, and **not** from `Section` class to `Handout` class. Without the dependency drawn in the class diagram, we will not know that `Section` class depends on `Handout` class. &lt;br>

Let's say if the `Section` class contains the class-level method as `public static void capacity()` (don't have the parameter required), then `Section` class does not depend on `Handout` class because `Handout` did not appear anywhere in the code for `Section` class. &lt;br>

As the `Section` class contains the class-level method as `public static void capacity(Handout h)`  where the parameter `h` must belong to `Handout` class, it means that `Section` class depends on `Handout` class, i.e. a relationship from `Section` to `Handout`. As stated earlier, there is no association from `Section` to `Handout`, thus dependency needs to be included.

> I note that you say there won't be an interface object in the object diagram as it's impossible to have an interface object. Good question, I never thought about it. I wanted to say I don't see why not, i.e. I think it can be correct because any implementation has a `is-a` relationship. So object A is an A, and object A is a B are both valid and therefore a:B can be correct, if argued that way. However, I also note in the textbook that:

> objectName:ClassName is meant to say 'an instance of ClassName identified as objectName'.

So according to that, if we write a:B, it is saying that an instance of `interface B` identified as `a`. An interface cannot be instantiated so saying that there are instances of an interface is not correct, therefore writing as a:B is not correct when argued this way. &lt;br>

These are my thoughts, I am more inclined to go with the latter because in the text book, generic notation for object diagrams is described as `instance:Class` -- there seems to be an emphasis that it is a **class**.

**1. :fas-info-circle: Should similar bugs under planned enhancements be considered NotInScope?**
</div>

<img width="716" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6d34bc17-c8c6-4bb8-8c7a-75198f15a131">

### **Context**:
- **Current Behavior**: Names containing substrings like `m/`, `a/`, or `e/` are misinterpreted as field prefixes, causing parsing errors.
- **Planned Enhancement**: The DG enhancement explicitly mentions fixing the issue for `m/`, but no similar mention exists for `a/` or `e/`.


### **Description**:

As shown in the screenshot above, our planned enhancements section in the DG explicitly states that the application will support names containing prefixes like `m/` as part of the name field (e.g., `n/John m/Doe`). This enhancement aims to prevent the parser from misinterpreting substrings like `m/` as the `major` prefix.

However, we have received **two related bug reports** regarding other prefixes (`a/` for address, `e/` for email) that are currently **not allowed in names**. These issues were not explicitly mentioned in the planned enhancements.

**Questions:**
1. Do these related issues qualify as part of the planned enhancement scope, given their similarity to the documented `m/` prefix enhancement since we think that they are duplicate bugs that can be fixed together at once?
2. Should we classify these issues as **"NotInScope"** or reject the bugs since they are mentioned in the planned enhancements section?



</panel>

**5. :fas-info-circle: Association Classes vs Dependencies**
</div>

Hi just wanted to clarify what the main difference is between Association Classes and Dependencies:

From my understanding, Dependencies are classes that does not store a reference to any other classes but relies on other classes to perform certain tasks and association is referred to classes that does in fact store references to other classes.

The following is a quote from the lecture notes on the course website that I have pasted for reference:
> Dependencies vs associations:
> 
> An association is a relationship resulting from one object keeping a reference to another object (i.e., storing an object in an instance variable). While such a relationship forms a dependency, we need not show that as a dependency arrow in the class diagram if the association is already indicated in the diagram. That is, showing a dependency arrow does not add any value to the diagram.
>
> Similarly, an inheritance results in a dependency from the child class to the parent class but we don't show it as a dependency arrow either, for the same reason as above.
>
> Use a dependency arrow to indicate a dependency only if that dependency is not already captured by the diagram in another way (for instance, as an association or an inheritance) e.g., class Foo accessing a constant in Bar but there is no association/inheritance from Foo to Bar.


My question is, in the photo pasted below for reference, doesn't the association class act like a dependency class as well? It does not store any references of other classes as shown in the example, rather just a utility base Class to store just a `startDate` and `returnDate` in example.

Great tip! Another approach I found is to consider using the [try-with-resources statement](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/tryResourceClose.html). This statement automatically manages the closing of resources, such as FileWriter and other types that implement `java.lang.AutoCloseable` or `java.io.Closeable`. 

By using try-with-resources, we can ensure that your file writers, scanners, and other resources are closed automatically at the end of the statement, even if an exception occurs. This can save time and prevent bugs related to resource management.

Hereâ€™s a quick example:
```java
try (FileWriter fileWriter = new FileWriter("output.txt")) ``{``
    // File Writing Logic Line 1
    // File Writing Logic Line 2
    // Code ...
    // File Writing Logic Line n
``}`` catch (IOException e) ``{``
    e.printStackTrace();
``}``
```

This way, there might not be a need to explicitly call fileWriter.close(), and it makes the code cleaner and less error-prone.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**13 :fas-comment:**
</div>

In CS2030 (the version taught by Prof Henry Chia) he advocates for all objects to be made immutable. For eg. if you want to change a `Task` object from being not-done to done, you should return a `new Task` rather than by modifying the boolean attribute tracking the "doneness" of the task. This makes the coding "safer" as there's no risk of accidentally changing the state / value of objects during runtime, but also makes it harder to program as the object changes after each state change (and the new object needs to slot into the place of the old one). 
</panel>

Composition allows 0 since it's only a one-way thing. The parent Class may or may not have it's children-Class(es) but the child classes Cannot exist without the parent class

> In CS2030 (the version taught by Prof Henry Chia) he advocates for all objects to be made immutable. For eg. if you want to change a `Task` object from being not-done to done, you should return a `new Task` rather than by modifying the boolean attribute tracking the "doneness" of the task. This makes the coding "safer" as there's no risk of accidentally changing the state / value of objects during runtime, but also makes it harder to program as the object changes after each state change (and the new object needs to slot into the place of the old one).

Prof Chia himself says that the extremely strict immutability is only a requirement for teaching purposes, and that in many real-life scenarios complete and absolute immutability is unergonomic, unperformant and possibly even unattainable at the systems level.
</panel>

> Will this affects encapsulation of the class?

This is a actually good point I did not consider.

Searching online, there is a highly upvoted stackoverflow question that discusses this problem, here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34571/how-do-i-test-a-class-that-has-private-methods-fields-or-inner-classes

I found one comment by Colin M which I found convincing, that says
> By testing private methods you are testing the implementation. This defeats the purpose of unit testing, which is to test the inputs/outputs of a class' contract.

So I guess in your specific situation, instead of trying to test directly on private fields of TaskList, you may test through its exposed interfaces (there should be some public method like getTask()). 

That said, it is just my immature idea. If anyone has a different opinion or approach, please feel free to comment below!
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/132#issuecomment-2320032654" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**9 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Just to add on:
When performing an auto reformat, IntelliJ by default collapses import from the same package as one single wildcard import when the number reaches 5 (which violates CS2103T coding standard). For example,
```java
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.TreeMap;
```
will be auto-reformatted to 
```java
import java.util.*;
```

To suppress this behaviour, go to File > Settings > Code Style > Java > Imports, set the two values in the rectangle to 9999.

<img width="738" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1d2e593d-2f40-458a-993f-46e8ab37942d">

If you want to limit the scope of this supression within the project only, you can change the scheme on top to Project before making the above changes. This way, other IntelliJ projects won't be affected and will still auto-collapse imports.

</panel>

</div>

The system import statements are separated by their groups / packages in [coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/index.html#package-and-import-statements), should we do the same for custom import statements, i.e. follow option 1 instead of option 2?

Option 1:
```
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileWriter;

import myfirstpackage.Main;
import myfirstpackage.Second;
import myfirstpackage.Third;

import mysecondpackage.Main;
import mysecondpackage.Second;

import mythirdpackage.Main;
```

Option 2:
```
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileWriter;

import myfirstpackage.Main;
import myfirstpackage.Second;
import myfirstpackage.Third;
import mysecondpackage.Main;
import mysecondpackage.Second;
import mythirdpackage.Main;
```

May be helpful:
If you are on Windows machine, run runtest.bat in */text-ui-test/ directory, and you **will not** expecting "Test result: PASSED" or "Test result: FAILED" outputs, you will only see the output from FC command.
If your are on *nix machine, run runtest.sh in */text-ui-test/ directory, and you **will** be expecting to see "Test result: PASSED" or "Test result: FAILED" outputs.
The 2 scripts are written differently, so they will not print the same set of outputs.

3. commit

If I recall correctly, inheriting from an abstract class means that the `Bar` class already has the default implementation of the `process()` method, so there is no need for `Bar` to have a `process()` method in the class. Having a `process()` method there means `Bar` is overriding the implementation in `Foo`, but taking it out means it uses the default implementation from `Foo`. Hence, taking it out will not cause a compile error, as stated in option 2.

Option 4 is a ~valid~ invalid statement as you said, as how `List&lt;String> list = new ArrayList();` works.
</panel>

**7. :fas-info-circle: UML Diagrams: Bidirectional vs opposite unidirectional associations**
</div>

From the textbook, it seems that two opposite two unidirectional associations between two classes does not always result in a bidirectional association. This was illustrated by the example:
```
class Person ``{``
    Cat pet;
    //...
``}``

class Cat``{``
    Person breeder;
    //...
``}``
```
I interpreted this as a class diagram like this:
<img width="344" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c2a84b20-a80a-475c-9c80-c4a2b82f4b2c">

Then, another example showcasing bidirectional association was given by this example:
```
class Dog ``{``
    Man man;
    // ...
``}``

class Man ``{``
    Dog dog;
    // ...
``}``
```

So with these two examples we see that simply having a class `B` attribute in class `A` and a class `A` attribute in class `B` might not always result in bidirectional association. In the first example, we say that the breeder might not be the owner of the pet so we separate the associations. Yet, in example 2, it does not seem quite apparent to me that the "`man`" and "`dog`" are referring to the same association. The `man ` in `Dog` could refer to the owner/breeder, etc.

I am not sure if it is correct but my take on this is that the attributes should be named in a way that provides the context so that a clear association can be established. If i renamed the `breeder` to `person` in the first example, how would I know if the association is bidirectional or two separate associations?
</panel>

**5. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Duke Level-1: Easily add optional indentations**
</div>

Hey guys I was looking around the web and Java documentation and found an interesting method that may be useful with adding the optional indentation.

Many would accomplish this by manually adding indentation to their string and print it out, for instance:
```java
System.out.println("    " + HORIZONTAL_LINE);
System.out.println("     Hello! I'm your friendly chat bot, how can I help you?");
```

But perhaps you have another function that produces a String with multiple lines:
```java
public static String createTwoLineString() ``{``
    // no way of adding space when printing? or is it
    return "first line\nsecond line";
``}``
```

Instead of rewriting the function to add spaces on new lines, you can use the [`String::indent(int)`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/String.html#indent(int)) method which adds the specified number of spaces at the front of each line instead.
```java
System.out.println(createTwoLineString().indent(4)); // prints the string with 4 spaces infront of each line
```

If you instead wish to add a prefix of mixed characters (eg: `"\t "` - tab and a space) instead of just spaces, you can instead write a function that uses the [`String::lines()`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/String.html#lines()) method which converts the `String` into a `Stream<String>` and apply Stream methods to add the prefix to the start of each line and combine into one String, or use the [`String.split("\n")`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/String.html#split(java.lang.String)) method which returns an array of String of the lines of the String and use some iterative approach (I recommend using [`StringBuilder`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/StringBuilder.html)) to create a new String with the prefix appended at each line.
</panel>

I think what @Incogdino has said is pretty much the gist of it. 

One point not that was brought up but not explicitly mentioned by @Incogdino is that git prefers to a do fast-forward merge (if possible) over a regular merge commit when using the `git merge branch_name` command and using the `--no-ff` flag forces git to create a merge commit; if you have two branches which both already have additional commits, `git merge` will create a merge commit as it is not possible to do a create fast-forward merge.

I think the video in the topics section ([Tools -&gt; Git and GitHub -&gt; branch: doing multiple parallel changes](https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s1.github.io/website/schedule/week3/topics.html#tools-git-and-github-branch-doing-multiple-parallel-changes)) is pretty good in explaining how to do both types of merges using SourceTree. First you want to go to your path variables, you can do this by searching `Edit the system environment variables` in Windows search bar which brings you to a `System Properties` window.

Then click `Environment Variables` which brings you to the `Environment Variables` window.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6eeb5585-73ad-485c-a8ff-b2b08a243bb9)

Then under the `System Variables` section, look in the `Variable` tab for `JAVA_HOME`.

![Screenshot 2024-08-31 145543](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4ee77a01-c74f-4100-a38b-24f11470b89b)

In there you should be able to change it to the Java 17 SDK probably called `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17`, you can double click the row to edit it and then after changing it press `Ok`.

List<String> strings = Files.readAllLines(Paths.get("data/rapgod.txt"));  //error prompted

java.util.List<String> strings = Files.readAllLines(Paths.get("data/rapgod.txt"));

import java.util.List;
```

```

     storage = new Storage(filePath);
     try ``{``
         tasks = new TaskList(storage.load());
     ``}`` catch (DukeException e) ``{``
         ui.showLoadingError();
         tasks = new TaskList();
     ``}``
 ``}``
```

When attempting the MoreOOP Increment, I notice this example, where a new Ui object is instantiated, and the `showLoadingError` method was called from that object. **2. :fas-info-circle: Variable scope in `switch`**
</div>

I've noticed that variables declared in the `case` block of a `switch` share the same scope.

For example,

```Java
switch (command) ``{``

case MarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
    int id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new MarkCommand(taskList, id);

case UnmarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
    int id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new UnmarkCommand(taskList, id);

``}``
```

if you try to compile and run this, there will be an error `Duplicate local variable id`.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7f4c37b7-c99a-4784-971e-0a51a6178450)

Currently, my workaround this issue is to introduce a closure by adding ```{````}``` around the `case` block, like in the code snippet below. This is quite readable in my opinion as it does not really disrupt the original flow of code. I believe it is also compliant with checkstyle since `./gradlew checkstyleMain` does not give me any errors.

```Java
switch (command) ``{``

case MarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD: ``{``
    int id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new MarkCommand(taskList, id);
``}``

case UnmarkCommand.COMMAND_WORD: ``{``
    int id = Integer.parseInt(rest) - 1;
    return new UnmarkCommand(taskList, id);
``}``

``}``
```

Are there other ways to handle this issue? Is this method reasonable?
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**6 :fas-comment:**

> Not sure if why this would work nor how did i encounter such issue in the first place, but here it is. Hope it helps.

The reason for the missing components was mentioned in [AB3](https://github.com/se-edu/addressbook-level3/blob/4eb130f32ef1a3b492ce25c741fb06defd26fad4/src/main/java/seedu/address/Main.java#L8-L23):

```java
/**
 * The main entry point to the application.
 *
 * This is a workaround for the following error when MainApp is made the
 * entry point of the application:
 *
 *     Error: JavaFX runtime components are missing, and are required to run this application
 *
 * The reason is that MainApp extends Application. In that case, the
 * LauncherHelper will check for the javafx.graphics module to be present
 * as a named module. We don't use JavaFX via the module system so it can't
 * find the javafx.graphics module, and so the launch is aborted.
 *
 * By having a separate main class (Main) that doesn't extend Application
 * to be the entry point of the application, we avoid this issue.
 */
```

You can view more details of this fix in this [commit](https://github.com/se-edu/addressbook-level3/commit/12bb91903e71ea1109e04f7369c2169f1c7be39a).
</panel>
