Hi @marchjlim 

This problem could be related to how IntelliJ is handling the project configuration as opposed to the code. 

1. Try `./gradlew clean build run`. And additionally try restarting your IDE for good measure. 
2. Try resetting Intellij's cache: **File** -&gt; **Invalidate Caches / Restart**
3. Go to your settings, go to **Build, Execution, and Deployment** -&gt; **Build tools** -&gt; **Gradle** and make sure that the build and run, and run tests are set to Gradle, and have not accidentally changed when you changed your commit. 

Another thing, when you say, 'run it on intellij', can I just confirm that you are using one of the methods mentioned [here?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6V6G3RyxEMk#t=13m44s) (i.e using the gradle window). 
Because if you are using the standard green run button, you might need to edit your Run configurations, by going to the drop down menu besides the run button, clicking **Edit configurations ... **, and look for the run configuration for the Main class. Click on it, and make sure that it points to the correct class. 

EDIT: Just a small note for point 3, in the same **Build tools** window, also just check that your Gradle JVM is set to the same version that you are using in terminal. (I got this tip from Issue #189, as recommended by @damithc in the subsequent comment)
</panel>

Hi @michaelyql 

So if I'm not wrong, the logger you're referring to is a variable, and the Singleton design pattern typically refers to a class which is set up in such a way that there can only be one instance, i.e the class will have a private constructor, a private static theOne variable, and a getInstance method that gets that Singleton instance for you.

By any chance, were you trying to ask whether the LogsCenter class is a singleton? If so, I think actually, the LogsCenter class is not a Singleton, as firstly, it's `init()` method(which acts as its constructor) is a public method. Secondly, there is no instance in the LogsCenter class which holds the Singleton, i.e a `theOne` variable.  

Hope that helps!
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**9 :fas-comment:**
</div>

> It's not Slapping hard and it's accessing field members is a big nono, especially if FullName might change or depend on object state.

I dont think not "SLAP"ping hard is the biggest issue, it is also not relevant in answering whether it violates LOD. Also as prof mentioned, how are you evaluating for SLAP? These are all single line return statements for the methods, unless you're referring to the examples themselves which without the body of the code, there is nothing to reference to evaluating SLAP. 

In answering Norbert's question, one tip to see if you violate LOD is to ask, (as a XXX object) am I accessing my own attributes or am I attempting to access other's attributes or methods?

Let's break down example 1 (example 2 is the same concept of example 1 except the client is doing less work)
> `lessonExample.getPerson().getName().fullname`

- lessonExample.getPerson() // returns a Person object, the object is an attribute stored within the Lesson object (lessonExample)
- .getName() // returns a Name object, thats within the Person object, at this point not violating LOD, depends on what you do after
- .fullname // accessing the attribute of the Name object (exposing information which shouldn't happen), violates LOD

I want to point out that in example 2 -- put yourself in the shoes of a Lesson object and now you're the client interacting with a Person object. In this case you're asking for the attributes from the Person object (and subsequently tearing information out), instead of telling the Person object to provide the information you need.

As Yadobler mentioned, the Person class should have a method that provides what you need (fullname), instead of allowing other classes to reach into the Name attribute and take the information.

How does this look like?

```
class Lesson ``{``
    Person person;
    // constructor and other methods
    String getPersonName() ``{``
        return this.person.getFullName();
    ``}``
``}``
```

```
class Person ``{``
    Name name;
    // other methods
    String getFullName() ``{``
        return this.name.getFullName();
    ``}``
``}``
```

```
class Name ``{``
    String fullname;
    // other methods
    String getFullName() ``{``
        return this.fullname;
    ``}``
``}``
```

In a closing note, the tell-dont-ask principle goes hand-in-hand with LOD, and as much as possible, you should redirect tasks to your attributes instead of plucking information out and doing it yourself. 

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/567#issuecomment-2456155958" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**10 :fas-comment:**
</div>

> However, if we throw an error in these cases, would that be seen as violating the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)?

I dont fully understand your questions.
Let me interpret your question. Assume this is your code
```
class Person ``{``
    ... //attributes
    public String editHours(int hoursForVolunteers) ``{`` // can be renamed to just "edit"
        return "Error: this person has no hours to edit";
    ``}``
    
    public String editDonationAmount(double amount) ``{`` // can be renamed to just "edit" also
        return "Error: this person has no amount to edit";
    ``}``
``}``
```

```
class Volunteer extends Person ``{``
    private int hours;
    
    public String editHours(int hours) ``{``
        // do stuff
        return "success";
     ``}``
``}``
```

```
class Donors extends Person ``{``
    private double amount;
    
    public String editDonationAmount(double amount) ``{``
        // do stuff
        return "success";
     ``}``
``}``
```

> LSP: Objects of a superclass should be able to be replaced with objects of a subclass without affecting the program.

For this there is application of substitutability. You could substitute `Person p = new Volunteer()` and do `p.editHours(1)`. The code is just not applying polymorphism, ie you need to know the subtype and apply the method. In terms of whether throwing errors, I presume you dont mean exceptions hence the String messages only. It will look a bit complicated if the methods throw errors, but nonetheless it isn't violating substitutability

Now if your code looks like

```
class Person ``{``
    public String edit(int i) throws Exception ``{``
        throw new Exception();
    ``}``
    // edit(double d)
``}``
```

```
class Volunteer extends Person ``{``
    public String edit(int i) throws Exception ``{``
        // do stuff and do not throw exception
    ``}``
``}``
```

This also does not violate LSP. But in the above example, polymorphism can be applied.

On your 2nd question:
> would enforcing role-specific validation (i.e., throwing an error when users attempt to edit a field not applicable to the instance) violate LSP?

I do not understand how your implementation is so I cant advise you. But if you see the 2nd example I gave, it is not necessary for validating (or type-checking / type-verifying) the types. I would think that, if the typechecking methods are in the subtypes but not supertype then yes it would violate LSP (eg. `boolean isVolunteer()` only appearing in Volunteer and not Person)

Hope my understanding of your question helps to answer
</panel>

>I think it is quite inefficient to write to file for every change as I/O operations are slow

Unless got few hundred concurrent requests, what are the chances it will actually be inefficient currently? File I/O is already quite efficient (see SQLite).

The value of logging correct atomic transactions seem to outweigh efficiency in this case not only because basically few people are using it, but also the task list is performing the function of book keeping, which is essentially an extremely basic database.

IMO, if you are at the point where speed of I/O operations matter, you can consider offloading that responsibility to a DB solution.

Personally, I just did the minimum to satisfy the requirement.

Edit: Thinking about your question, perhaps a better question to ask is how can i design the code such that I can provide an interface for my code to talk to, such that I don't care about the I/O implementation (algorithm implementation). For that, you can consider some design patterns like Adapter pattern or strategy pattern. But whether or not it is worth the effort to write that into code for a simpler problem like this, is debatable. It depends on your personal objectives.
</panel>

> Hi since assert statements are meant for testing important assumptions that should already hold (potential errors should already be handled such that the assumptions should hold) should we catch it if it's actually thrown. 

I don't think assertions should be "caught". You want to find out whether or not assertions are actually true asap, you don't want to try stopping the assertions from telling you something is wrong with your code.

From the course website:

> This is because an assertion failure indicates a possible bug and the sooner the execution stops, the safer it is.


</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/252#issuecomment-2338814103" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**7 :fas-comment:**
</div>

> Since if perhaps errors/exceptions are potentially alr accounted for/handled, what's the use of assert statements

Raising errors/exceptions and assertions deal with different things.

From the course website:

> The raising of an exception indicates an unusual condition created by the user (e.g. user inputs an unacceptable input) or the environment (e.g., a file needed for the program is missing).
An assertion failure indicates the programmer made a mistake in the code (e.g., a null value is returned from a method that is not supposed to return null under any circumstances).


</panel>

> like to build a facebook competitor, the app will need to be huge and complex given how many features facebook has, so it sounds hard/unfeasible to develop in one-shot sequentially, not to mention you are developing a competitor, so it needs to be better than facebook (how? add novel features probably i.e. iterative)
> 
> path coverage in many cases is much harder to achieve than statement, and can be illustrated with even a simple example like in the textbook, so id put my money on that option

Yup I agree that the path coverage option is the best answer, but what if the iterative approach option was a standalone question, would it be correct and incorrect?

Also, I do agree that it makes sense to do it iteratively, but I think my main concern has to do with whether or not to follow the guideline I mentioned, given that, that is the only explicit guideline given in the textbook (I think? correct me if I'm wrong), to decide sequential vs iterative. 
</panel>

IntelliJ has local history, right click on file, select local history as shown from option menu, click on show history and revert to your change. Note this is different from git and is IntelliJ's autosave feature. This saves all changes even uncommitted ones and shows all the way back to class creation. If you did not use the IDE to code, look for stashed changes and please start using the IDE in the future.

<img width="317" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b9345d3a-8a87-4d69-8c90-b2813e497d25">

<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

By default, Local History is configured to store revisions for the last 5 working days (that is, days when the file was modified). In the Settings dialog ( Ctrl Alt 0S ) , go to Advanced Settings. In the IDE section, provide the desired retention period value in the Duration of storing changes in Local History field.
</panel>

Thank you prof it works now, 
the problem was not with the root, the problem was with the branch, I was deploying from master branch, as I presumed gh pages was the name of the working branch for the tutorial/guide (like the switch-to-markbind branch), before being merged into the master branch, 

As Jekyll and all other github pages deployments run from master branch/docs; I believed that would be the corresponding setting in our repo as well.

Turns out gh-pages is a separate branch maintained by the Github Actions, not us; so for Markbind that needs to be active irrespective of other tp settings.

Thank you once again for your help.

For the IP, I also believe that there is no point to defining a static variable for the task type, especially when it is used in 2 isolated methods and nowhere else. Perhaps within the javadocs remark that D is the short-form for Deadline so that people who are not familiar with this IP can understand what it means. 

On the flip-side, suppose that you want to change the format from "D" to "Deadline", you have to replace these 2 instances of the magic literal, which is doable. 1. Creating a PAT that allows workflow in github
2. Going to IntelliJ > Settings > Version Control > Github > Sign in by token and adding the PAT
3. Going to Start > Settings > Windows Credentials manager and deleting my old git credentials

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/210" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2. :fas-info-circle: Naming Booleans and their Getter Methods**
</div>

### Problem
When a class contains a private Boolean field (e.g. `isComplete`) and said Boolean is exposed via a getter method, it is intuitive to name the getter method as `isComplete()`. However, this would lead to a duplicate in naming as `isComplete` is already used to name the variable.

In this case, what would be a better way to name the Boolean variable and its corresponding getter method?

### Attempts at Resolution
1. My current implementation would name the Boolean field as `complete`, and its getter method would be named `isComplete()`.

2. However, it can be argued that naming both the Boolean field and the getter method `isComplete` and `isComplete()` respectively is also fine.
This is because accessing the variable directly and calling the getter method are syntactically different (one uses brackets, the other does not).
In addition, only `isComplete()` can be called from outside the classâ€”assuming the appropriate data-hiding precautions are taken.

3. Another possible option could be to name it `isComplete` and to name its getter as `isIsComplete()`, but this sounds slightly silly to me. 

### Following Conventions
The [coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/#naming) used in this course recommends that Boolean variables/methods should be named to sound like Booleans but makes no mention of cases like these. The [Google Java style guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html) provided also does not address this issue. 

### External Sources
Google searches have yielded me some of these discussions on Stack Overflow:
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5322648/for-a-boolean-field-what-is-the-naming-convention-for-its-getter-setter
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4851337/setter-for-a-boolean-variable-named-like-isactive
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49273722/what-should-be-the-name-of-getter-method-for-a-boolean-variable-starting-with-i

These posts mostly have answers that recommend solution 1, but seems to be based on the [JavaBeans Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaBeans#Code_example) (see Boolean property `deceased`). Hence, it might not be applicable to the conventions used in this course.

### Help Needed
Has anyone encountered this issue with naming while working on their iP? If so, how did you to resolve it? Thanks in advance. :)
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/210#issuecomment-2335145947" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Thanks for your responses over the past few days. It has been helpful to see the different approaches taken to tackle this issue.

### Context
As requested by @tckeong, this question stems from the implementation of `Task` class in the iP, where a Boolean variable is required to keep track of its completion status.
```
public class Task ``{``
    private boolean isComplete; // the boolean of interest
    
    // a setter method which is used
    public void setComplete(boolean isComplete) ``{``
        this.isComplete = isComplete;
    ``}``

    // other methods that are not relevant
```
However, there has been no real need for a getter method to check for the Boolean `isComplete` in the iP. Hence, this question is **purely hypothetical** and has no real implications for the actual `Task` class.

### Suggestions
The suggestions provided have their own merit, but I cannot fully agree with some of them as the intent of the method would change with the change in naming.

> `getComplete()` and `getIsComplete()`.
- `getComplete()` and `getIsComplete()` follow the standard convention for getter methods but fails to comply with the coding standard where Boolean variables/methods should be named to sound like Booleans. These names do not immediately suggest that the method will return a Boolean value and could be possibly misinterpreted.

> `checkIsComplete()` indicates that the method checks if the task is complete.
- The method never checks if the task is completeâ€”it only returns the Boolean variable. This could lead to a misinterpretation of the method's intent as well.

> `hasComplete()` provides an alternative name for the getter method.
- `hasComplete()` follows the convention for naming Boolean methods, but the word 'has' wouldn't sound like proper English when used in conditional statements, i.e. `if(task.hasComplete())`.
- Providing an alternative name also doesn't seem like good practice, since having multiple words that mean the same thing can confuse other readers (and yourself) as the codebase grows larger.
For example, `evaluate`, `calculate`, `determine` and `compile` are all verbs that could be used interchangeably and mean the same thing unless otherwise specified. `fetch`, `retrieve` and `get` is another good example.
- This inconsistent use of verbs would make it hard to keep track what concept/action each verb maps to.
As such, I can't fully agree with this approach either.

### Down to Preference
As it stands, I would still prefer my (and @psh12320's) approach of treating the private field as a flag `complete` and the getter method with the Boolean-sounding name of `isComplete()`, though this would be a biased opinion.

I believe that this is incredibly subjective and ultimately boils down to personal preference. At the end of the day, being consistent within the codebase would be the most important.

Will leave this issue as open for a few more days in case of more discussion, but will close it if there are no responses after this point. Thanks again for taking the time to chime in on this!
</panel>

@zaidansani 

I think your indentation example makes a lot of sense, and I think any regular JS/TS/React users (including myself) would  appreciate the familiarity of the indentation style (it looks just like any other arrow function). So I agree with your idea on this one. 

I would recommend anyone pondering about this issue to stay away from the first example that I showed. As Zaidan mentioned, if the variable name we are assigning to is very long, the case statements that have to align to the start of the switch statement will have a lot of leading whitespace, which I find only adds more mental load to the reader.

Furthermore, it would mean that different switch expressions would have different levels of indentation for their case statements, since the start of the switch statement depends on the length of the variable we're assigning to. It would be very difficult to align the case statement indentation across multiple switch expressions, let alone just two. 
</panel>

Hmm, my train of thought was also to use mocks/stubs. You could extend the original class and override existing methods/write new methods that you need to control/inspect so I don't think there should be that much reimplementation.

Maybe you could try something like this?
```java
public class TaskListStub extends TaskList ``{``
    private List<Task> tasksStub = new ArrayList<>();
    
    // Override some existing method to modify behaviour for testing
    @Override
    public void addTask(Task task) ``{``
        tasksStub.add(task);
    ``}``
    
    // Additional method to check for the modified behaviour without
    // implementing a getter in TaskList to access private fields.
    public boolean wasTaskAdded(Task task) ``{`` 
        return tasksStub.contains(task);
    ``}``
``}``
```

It seems that the warnings are due to the runners using outdated Node.js versions, rather than an issue with your code itself. Since the workflows are working fine, I'm pretty sure the warnings can be ignored.

However, if the warnings bothers you, you can avoid them by upgrading the versions in the `.yml` file:
1) [Upgrade gradle/wrapper-validation-action  to gradle/actions/wrapper-validation@v4](https://github.com/gradle/wrapper-validation-action?tab=readme-ov-file)
2) [Upgrade setup-java to v2](https://github.com/actions/setup-java/blob/main/docs/switching-to-v2.md)

It should look something like this? (Copy at your own risk, untested)
```diff
 - name: Validate Gradle Wrapper
-  uses: gradle/wrapper-validation-action@v3
+  uses: gradle/actions/wrapper-validation@v4

 - name: Setup JDK 17
-  uses: actions/setup-java@v1
+  uses: actions/setup-java@v2
   with:
+    distribution: 'zulu'
     java-version: '17'
     java-package: jdk+fx
```
</panel>

**4 :fas-comment:**

Hi! I searched up the web and found possible reasons why this could happen. 

If we type `git add *`, Git will add all files in the current directory to the staging area except for those that are listed in the `.gitignore` file or those that match the patterns defined in it. 

The .gitignore file may not be added to the staging area when you run `git add *` because of the following reasons:
- The `.gitignore`file is ignored by another `.gitignore` entry
- The `.gitignore` file is not in the directory where you're running `git add *`
- The `.gitignore` file was already added and committed previously

To explicitly add `.gitignore` file, we can run `git add .gitignore`. To add all modified files including `.gitignore` we can simply run `git add .`

Hope this helps!
</panel>

The error message you are seeing indicates that there is a mismatch between the versions of the Java runtime you are using and the version of the JavaFX library in the project. It seems like you are using Java 8. To double check run `java --version` or you can go to `File -&gt; Project Structure` in IntelliJ and check that the SDK you are using is **Java 17**. If not, switch the SDK to Java 17. But if you are using Mac then specific **Azul JDK 17** distribution must be used, just having Java 17 would not suffice. You may follow [this guide](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaInstallationMac.html) to install the specific SDK. Once installed, you can go back to project structure and select `zulu-17` as your SDK instead.

Hope this helps!

```
Unknown command! 
```

```
You have cancelled the ___ command.
```

Is this a fixable bug for feature freeze?

**2. :fas-info-circle: Tester reports bug about validation being too strict**
</div>


Basically, we have a data field that only accepts alphanumeric and dashes, and a tester reported that the condition is too strict. Based on the feature freeze, we know we are not allowed to fix this, but should we reject this (for being a suggestion) or accept it as a planned enhancement?
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/639" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3. :fas-info-circle: Handling an abnormal input in a different way, can fix or cannot fix?**
</div>


One of my team's commands has two related (same input field) but different bugs reported.
1) Input does not handle integer overflow/large integers like `9999999999999`, the app does not do anything or return any error message (app misbehaves)
2) Input does not handle inputs with leading zeros, returns an empty list, but behaves properly (doesn't crash, etc).

I will accept Bug 1 since it is a functionality bug that breaks the app, but the input is not a normal usage. But if I fix Bug 1, Bug 2 will be slightly affected due to sharing the same validation (they are both the same input field).

More specifically, before the change, the app accepts leading zeros and returns an empty list. After the change, the app does not accept numbers with more than 3 digits, and therefore doesn't accept most inputs with leading zeros.

The constraint of the input field is NOT limited to 3 digits, it is just a side effect of the range of numbers accepted.

In this case, can I fix Bug 2 since it is _now rejecting valid inputs_, or cannot fix since (before fixing Bug 1) it simply _accepts seemingly 'unsuitable' values_.

Edit: We would say that inputs with leading zeros are valid but unsuitable and not normal usage.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/218#issuecomment-2333388246" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**4 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Here are the steps I took to resolve this error:

1. Copy-paste the links on the internet. 

2. Once done, the files `configuration_1_3.dtd` and `suppressions_1_2.dtd` will be downloaded. 

3. You can paste those files within the same `config/checkstyle` folder as `checkstyle.xml` and `suppressions.xml`.

4. After doing the above, you can write the following code instead:

``` xml
<!DOCTYPE module PUBLIC
        "-//Checkstyle//DTD Checkstyle Configuration 1.3//EN"
        "configuration_1_3.dtd">

```

The same can be done for `suppressions.xml`.

There will be no longer be any URI not registered error.


</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/210#issuecomment-2333468546" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**5 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I believe solution 1 is the cleanest and most 'intuitive' approach. 

By naming the boolean field `complete` and its getter method as `isComplete()`, we maintain clarity and adhere to the coding standard of having method names that represent an action. Additionally, the field name remains easy to understand and intuitive for developers even though it doesn't contain a prefix. 

Other solutions such as using `getIsComplete()` as a getter method name is rather verbose for something seemingly simple and may not easy for developers to grasp. 

I think that solution 1 is balanced in terms of being readable and complying with coding standards.

Then again, in CS2103T, we should be following the coding standards given here regardless. 
Rationale: Just follow it ðŸ˜


</panel>

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Yes. When you run git push while on a branch without specifying the remote (like origin) or the branch name, Git will automatically push to the branch's corresponding remote branch. This works because Git keeps track of the relationship between your local branch and its upstream counterpart on the remote. Typically, when you create a new branch off of a remote branch or when you clone a repository, Git will set up this tracking relationship for you. So, as long as your branch is tracking the correct remote branch, you can simply use git push without any extra arguments, and it will push to the appropriate remote branch by default.
</panel>

1. Ensure that the "resources" file is marked as a source file and not a resource file. You can do this by checking that the file icon next to the word resources looks like this:
<img width="92" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e1081bdf-ddaf-4bab-a9d4-d234daee488c">

(Initially mine had a yellow logo instead)

2. Not sure if this affects anything, but I also ensured that the Main, MainWindow, DialogBox and Launcher classes were outside my `duke` package

3. If you're using Intellij, right click on the import statements and select "Show Context Actions". There should be a list of actions that appears (mainly adding different modules and dependencies). I just clicked on each one until the error messages all went away.

Thanks @damithc , @k-hian and @QinHaichen12 for help on this!

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/567" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on LSP and Role-Specific Field Editing Behavior**
</div>

**Description:**

Our team is working on a feature where users can manage contacts with different roles: `Volunteer` (subclass of `Person`), `Donor` (subclass of `Person`), `Partner` (subclass of `Person`), and `Person` (default). Each role has specific fields, such as `hours` for Volunteers and `donatedAmount` for Donors.

**Our concern:**

Allowing users to edit role-specific fields for the wrong role (e.g., editing `hours` for a non-Volunteer) could cause bugs. However, if we throw an error in these cases, would that be seen as violating the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)?

Since the `edit` function should ideally work across all instances of `Person` and its subclasses, would enforcing role-specific validation (i.e., throwing an error when users attempt to edit a field not applicable to the instance) violate LSP?

Any insights on this would be greatly appreciated!

</panel>

> From my opinion, I feel like the first diagram is more concise and easier to read, as the both of the conditions has to be true to execute the intended behavior. while if one of it is false, it will skip the execution of the behavior. It seems a bit redundant to include another branch node as it doesn't result in a different branch/behaviour if valid argument is true and boolean check is false. But actually diagram 2 might also create a bit of ambiguity in the second diagram, which will be explain below
> 
> For the second question, I am concerning that is there ambiguous for reader as now it is in a separated branch, reader might be confused as they not sure what is the expected value for `booleanChecked` now, as it can be understand as
> 
>     1. `booleanChecked` supposed to `true` to process the intended behavior, then `!booleanChecked` which is `false` will be branched out (As what is shown in diagram 1)
> 
>     2. `booleanChecked` supposed to be `false` to process the intended behavior, then `!booleanChecked` will be `true` and branch out (This is different from what the diagram 1 is representing now)
> 
> 
> Hence, maybe `booleanChecked == true` will be more clear? But not sure is writing `[booleanChecked]` a more concise representation for it.
> 
> Not sure is my understanding on the right track, correct me if I am wrong : D

Hmm, I was of the idea that in the spirit of concise code, a boolean in a guard clause can be expressed without using `== true`
For example,
`if (isPresent == true) ``{`` ... ``}```
and 
`if (isPresent) ``{`` ... ``}```
are equivalent. I feel that if it's clear to the developer/user that what is being checked is a boolean, in this example `isPresent`, it should be fine to leave it as so. Thanks again for your inputs.

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/268" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡You can fix trailing whitespace issues in your source code with a single command**
</div>

While running checkstyle on my codebase a frequent issue was that I would get the error `Line matches the illegal pattern 'Trailing whitespace'.` Manually checking for these is painful because the human eye cannot easily see a trailing whitespace.

You can run the following command

# For Mac users
Use the following command and replace `filename` with the relative path of the file
```bash
sed -i '' 's/[ \t]*$//' test.txt
``` 
You can even put all the filenames in a txt file and then do
```bash
while read -r file; do
    sed -i '' 's/[ \t]*$//' "$file"
done < filelist.txt
```

# For Linux users
Use the below command on your terminal
```
sed -i 's/[ \t]*$//' filename
```
You can even put all the filenames in a txt file and then do
```bash
while read -r file; do
    sed -i 's/[ \t]*$//' "$file"
done < filelist.txt
```

# For Windows Users
You can use the below PowerShell command

```PowerShell
(Get-Content filename) | ForEach-Object ``{`` $_.TrimEnd() ``}`` | Set-Content filename
```
Or you can use the below for a list of files stored in a txt file
```PowerShell
Get-Content filelist.txt | ForEach-Object ``{`` 
    (Get-Content $_) | ForEach-Object ``{`` $_.TrimEnd() ``}`` | Set-Content $_ 
``}``
```


</panel>

**2. :fas-info-circle: Clarification for Error Message Update during Feature Freeze**
</div>

Our group has a command, `renameTag` with the format `renameTag ot/OLD_TAG nt/NEW_TAG`, that aims to rename all tags with `OLD_TAG` to `NEW_TAG`.

One of our PE-D testers found an [issue](https://github.com/AY2425S1-CS2103T-W12-1/tp/issues/218) with our error messages where
* If both `OLD_TAG` and `NEW_TAG` are empty strings (or just whitespaces), then a `Tags should be alphanumeric` error message is shown
* If both `OLD_TAG` is an empty string (or just whitespaces) but `NEW_TAG` is valid, then a `Tag is not found` error message is shown

We agree that the error messages should be consistent. Are we allowed to change the error message in both cases to be `Tags should be alphanumeric and not empty`? Tip for macOS users:

I initially encountered an issue when trying to merge branch-Level-7 into master on my mac. The option to merge without fast-forwarding didnâ€™t appear in the popup. After some some time I eventually discovered there's a default setting in Sourcetree that ensures all merges create a merge commit, preventing fast-forward merges.

To enable this setting:

1. Go to Sourcetree settings by using the shortcut (Command ,) or by selecting Sourcetree > Settings from the top menu bar

2. Navigate to the Git section

3. Tick the box "Do not fast-forward when merging, always create commit."

</div>

When comparing ACTUAL.TXT and EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT I realised I was failing the test because my ACTUAL.TXT file had whitespaces at the end of some lines specifically at lines where the script writes inputs. 

To fix this I added the following lines of code in the `runtest.sh` file after both text files were converted to UNIX:
```
# trim trailing whitespace
sed -i '' 's/[[:space:]]*$//' ACTUAL.TXT
sed -i '' 's/[[:space:]]*$//' EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT
```
These commands search for any whitespaces at the end of both text files and removes them. 

I'm not sure how to do the same on Windows or if this is common practise at all so maybe someone else can chime in below.

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/84#issuecomment-2313152913" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

> The reason this happens is because you keep creating a new instance of the scanner every time the loop repeats.
> 
> When the first instance of the scanner is created, it takes in an input. When ran without a script, this is the user keyboard input. When ran with a script, this is the input text file provided.
> 
> Thus on every loop iteration, a new instance of the scanner means that the previous input stream gets reset and it awaits for new user/ file input. Since there is no other file supplied, you get the error that you see, "Exception in thread "main" java.util.NoSuchElementException: No line found". The program then terminates and gives you the mismatch between your expected and actual files.
> 
> To resolve this, you can create your scanner instance outside of the while loop.

I see, ty for the help!
</panel>

I would like to share my thoughts as well. My opinion is to make things that are supposed to _always_ be immutable, immutable and things that are not immutable not immutable. Things should not be immutable by default unless enforced by the programming language (e.g. you are using a functional programming language).

When you create a class that is final, it should be a _final_ commitment. Every other piece of code that will interact with your class will try to make a copy just to make modifications. Some pieces of concurrent code may also assume that it will never change and treat it as safe for [repeatable reads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read%E2%80%93write_conflict).

When a new requirement comes and forces us to change our class to not be final, then we are breaking all these assumptions we initially had. We may have to analyse every usage, which is very time consuming.

That being said:
- The stakes are much lower for `private` and unexposed (i.e. no getters) fields since it is only visible to the current class. So don't worry so much about it
- I don't see much difference in making a class `final`...but these people seem to have quite a bit to say: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/218744/good-reasons-to-prohibit-inheritance-in-java

---

On a separate note,

> I think for the future when we add more stuff to the code, if we make it immutable its gonna take a really long time to load it. So I personally jsut did a mutable one

There is a way to make immutable objects "faster" but at the cost of code complexity (since Java does not support it natively). Can take a look at [persistent data structures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistent_data_structure). Clojure is an example of a language that supports it natively.


</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/22#issuecomment-2308428343" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I think that enums offer two main possible benefits:
1. Slight speed increase (as we will learn/have learned in CS2100)
2. Type checking for constants

I agree with @cth06-Github that currently there is no need to use enums for the commands. Currently, there is only one usage of such an enum. For example, if we had an enum like WinstonJin has mentioned:

```java
enum Commands ``{``
    TODO("todo"),
    DEADLINE("deadline"),
    // ...
``}``
```

The rest of our codebase will only use this enum once: when we are parsing the first word from the user's input and checking what to do:
```java
switch (Commands.valueOf(input)) ``{``
    case Commands.TODO:
        // run todo
        break;
    // ...
``}``
```

Since it is only used once, there is no point in separating it into another enum. We should make an enum only if there is somewhere else in our code where we need to use the `Commands` enum. This way, we can leverage on the type checking the compiler does to ensure both values are the same.
</panel>

</panel>

```java
>     public void executeDelete_correctInput() ``{``
>         TaskList taskList = new TaskList(new ToDo("test"));
>         DeleteCommand deleteCommand = new DeleteCommand(0);

>             deleteCommand.execute(taskList, new Ui(), new Storage("data/test.txt"));

>             fail("Exception thrown when it should not have been thrown.");
>         ``}``
>         assertEquals(0, taskList.getSize());
>     ``}``
> ``}``
```
> 
> The build failing previously occurred when I have yet to run the application before calling `gradlew clean build`. After calling `gradlew run`, the file in directory `data/test.txt` gets created and `gradlew build` works properly, passing the test cases.
> 
> I reckon Github Action runs a similar procedure internally when building your application. Since the file path `data/test.txt` does not exist on building, the test case is bound to fail and thus the build.

One hint is to check the branches that exist on the remote first:
'
git branch -r
'

@somethingfishyfishy I think another concern would be performance and memory. Creating an enumeration with 10001 values (0 to 10000) would be extremely inefficient in terms of both memory usage and performance as compared as an if statement that checks if value between 0 and 10000. The extra memory is also not needed because each value from 0 to 10000 serves no other meaning besides representing the integer value, whilst enumeration is best used when each value has a distinct semantic meaning.

</panel>

I believe you're right that related classes should be grouped into the same package. In your case, if you have an abstract class and three classes that extend it, it indeed does makes sense to bundle them together in one package since they share a common purpose or functionality. Creating a separate "exceptions" package for your exception classes is also another good way to organise your code.


> following the convention that files in the same package have to be of the same type

Regarding the above, I believe the convention that files in the same package have to be of the same "type" is more about maintaining logical cohesion rather than enforcing a strict rule so I would think that both your suggested ways of packaging your files would be acceptable so long as it makes logical sense.

For your 2nd question, I don't think every file needs to be in a package, but it's generally good practice to place all your classes, including your main executable (e.g. "Duke"), in packages to avoid naming conflicts and to better organize your code.

Regarding the error you got, yes I believe you are right that the error you're seeing is related to the change in the directory structure.. It seems like it happened because the references to your main class in other files (like `EXPECTED.TXT`, `README.md`, `runtest.bat`) would be outdated after moving it and need to be updated to reflect the new package structure. For example, if your class was previously referenced as `DGPT`, it would now need to be referenced as `main.DGPT` (if you put it in a package named `main`).
</panel>

</div>


<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/forum/issues/275" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**1. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡ Custom/External Fonts in JavaFX via CSS**
</div>

Was pretty frustrating to figure out, with ChatGPT + Internet searches giving confusing contradicting info, so here's what worked for me if anyone wants to know:

---

### 1. Get your font files

Generally of the filetypes `.otf` or `.ttf`. Create a new folder `fonts` in your `src/main/resources` directory. Place the files there.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb7a9008-046a-409d-a3a1-faab1de60ddb)

### 2. Load fonts

In your `Main` class, or whatever extends `Application` and is where your GUI runs from, import

```java
import javafx.scene.text.Font;
```

And add the following in the constructor:

```java
Font.loadFont(getClass().getResourceAsStream("/fonts/<font-filename>"), v);
```

- Replace `<font-filename>` with the filename of the font you want to use, e.g. `comic.ttf` that is present in `resources/fonts`. 
- `v` is the default font size.

### 3. Add fonts to CSS

Whenever you specify a font in CSS, simply replace that string with the name of the font you have loaded. 
```css
.button ``{``
    ...
    -fx-font: bold 16px "Comic Sans MS";
    ...
``}``

.text-field ``{``
    ...
    -fx-font-family: "Montserrat SemiBold";
    ...
``}``
```

#### Note:

You might want to check the exact name of the font, since it can be different from the filename of that font. Make sure in the CSS sheet you use the **actual name** (e.g. `Montserrat SemiBold` or `Comic Sans MS`) and not the **filename** (`Montserrat-SemiBold` or `comic`).

You can obtain the names by:

```java
Font font1 = Font.loadFont(getClass().getResourceAsStream("/fonts/Inter-Medium.ttf"), 18); // load font from file
font1.getName(); // gets you name of the font
```

### Voila!

You can now show off to ~~the world~~ your teammates your excellent taste in font choice. 

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c58c41d8-b12e-4c79-9c96-10f83474a76e)

I think `Ui` is for receiving input while `Parser` is for processing the input. For example, `Ui` might have a `readLine` method to receive input from the user, but it will pass the raw input to `Parser` to make sense of the input.

For me, my `Parser` class has a static method to parse the description of a task, and a static method to parse the slash arguments for a task. So, I would do something like this:
```
String description = Parser.parseDescription(input);
Map<String, String> arguments = Parser.parseArguments(input);
```
This extracts the values I need from the input line, and then I can do something else with those values.

And I used `try` `catch` in my `main()` method to print the message from the exception via `e.getMessage()`. If you have added JavaFX, you could add the `try-catch` block in the `getResponse()` method and instead of printing, you can return the error message as a String. Both this method would allow you to continue using the application even after the error is thrown.

Hey y'all, I'm from the same team as @Jianwen0451 and we managed to fix the issue. We are pretty sure that we have set up the team repo correctly (codecov, tokens, repo settings and all that) but the Java CI just wasn't running.

Here's how we fixed it: 
1. Create a new workflow in GitHub Actions
2. Choose Java with Gradle
3. Rename the file to something else other than gradle.yml (gradletest.yml for example)
4. Copy and paste the content of gradle.yml into gradletest.yml
5. Commit to repo

After we did these steps, we had two Java CI's and they both started running. Now, we can disable the new Java CI workflow and the old one should now be functioning correctly. So basically, adding a new workflow kickstarted the Java CI.

As for what caused this issue in the first place, we have no clue.
</panel>

</panel>
